body: Nice! Performance of `groovydoc` definitely needs improvement
@paulk-asert It looks good for me. What do you think about the PR?
on my TODO list to review - at first glance I am optimistic
Backported to 2.5.x and 2.6.x
I did a quick review. All looks great.
72 hours have gone. I will merge it soon if no one has objections.
Merged. Thanks!
Groovy is using Ivy 2.5.0-rc1 on master and 2.6.x branches. Feel free to give it a try.

The PR looks great for me. Out of curiosity, why does the  helper method cause the issue(`GenericsUtils.extractPlaceholders(GenericsUtils.findParameterizedType(declaringClassForDistance, actualReceiverForDistance));
 `)? I will set aside some time to investigate.
It was extracting the actual type argument of `String` rather than the type `Trie`.
+1, you actually fixed something on my TODO list to look at today! :-)
@paulk-asert it's better to add your tests too
@jwagenleitner Gotcha 😉
Merged. I forgot to add the "closes #728" comment adjustment. Feel free to close this or I will do it as  a side effect of some minor doco changes tomorrow before I kick off the candidate creation.
Thanks for the merge!
Merged. Thanks :-)

+1 on the idea behind the change but probably worth running the checkBinaryCompatibility task first. Some of the changes look suspect but possibly have workarounds like bridging methods in some cases.

What does the japi report say?

Paul, as you can see, the changed API are just about tool itself(i.e. groovy console), should we care about binary compatibility?

After changes:

Status | Fully Qualified Name
-- | --
MODIFIED | groovy.inspect.swingui.AstBrowser

NEW | groovy.inspect.swingui.ButtonOrDefaultRenderer
NEW | groovy.inspect.swingui.ButtonOrTextEditor
MODIFIED | groovy.inspect.swingui.ScriptToTreeNodeAdapter
MODIFIED | groovy.ui.Console
NEW | groovy.ui.ConsolePreferences

It would be good to help fix some of the windows locking issues. This change looks reasonable to me on first glance. We should do a quick check if there are any negative performance impacts by not having that caching in place.

Yes, ideally we'd fix all of those. I only found this particular one because it broke one of our integration tests that was testing AST transforms. I will do a pass over the code base and fix the other places I find.

@paulk-asert I think that cache is mostly an optimization for remote resources. My best bet is that it was introduced back in the day to make Applets faster. With jars in the local file system I see no such issue. I've tried deactivating the cache globally in Gradle and didn't see a slowdown in our performance tests. But I'd rather not do such a heavy-handed approach on our side, as some Gradle plugins indeed might be depending on URL caching for other purposes.
This is ready for another review.

I know IDEA, grails and some other tools integrate with GroovyConsole. I haven't looked into how deep into the class hierarchy that integration goes. So possibly not a problem but hard to tell. Best to keep binary compatibility if in doubt. Looks like there are easy fixes for most of the ones here anyway, so we might as well head down that path and see if we can fix all. I think some $$bridge methods and deprecated object overloaded methods should cover most of the cases.
OK. Let's leave it as it is for the time being...
let's look at this again in a couple of weeks
merged, thanks!

+1 for GROOVY_2_5_X, GROOVY_2_6_X and master
Small thing but I pondered whether "Show Classpath" might be slightly more consistent with View menu than "List Classpath". Possibly slightly better than "Inspect Classpath" which also seemed a possibility but I'd be happy with any of those.
Merged. Thanks.

Merged. Thanks!
Thanks!

In `DelegateASTTransformation`, we skip methods from `GroovyObject`. Here I chose to look for ones annotated with `@Generated`. At the moment, I believe this is identical behavior but if we start making more use of `@Generated` I think the approach chosen here will be the correct approach. We should consider retrofitting this approach for `@Delegate`.
Nice work John!

Added stricter checking to only adjust if the first constructor parameter is of the enclosing class type. Not sure it's necessary, but don't think the check adds much overhead and may be better than just adding just any number of pre-pended annos.
Thanks!
Merged with deprecated and bridge methods added to address binary compatibility for 2_5_X and then deprecated methods removed for master.

At first, thanks for your contribution. 
I wonder whether you have tested the performance?
Merged. Thanks!
Looks good. I'll merge it. Thanks!

Merged, thanks! Since you removed the line:
sourceSets = [sourceSets.main]
it means that when you run the check task, all of the configurations will be tested, e.g.
main, examples and test for the rootProject.
This will slow down our quality build:
http://ci.groovy-lang.org/viewType.html?buildTypeId=Groovy_CoverageIndyRuntime
but I have left it in place for now. If we feel it is too slow, we can go back and alter this.
Thanks again.

Merged, thanks! I closed the PR for GROOVY_2_5_X too. I already updated ASM on that branch and we'll merge your commit to 2_5_X if needed after a bit more due diligence on what ASM7_EXPERIMENTAL gives us. Thanks again!
+1 for master and GROOVY_2_5_X
Merged, thanks!
Merged.

Hi @aalmiray / @blackdrag , I wonder why the auto-generated setters and getters, as well as equals / hashcode are not also marked as `@Generated`. I have the following class: I am getting this coverage report: I am using Groovy 2.5.1 and JaCoCo 0.8.1. This class was supposed to have 100% code coverage. Also something I get coverage saying I have not covered all branches of a line, but the line has just one branch: What do you guys think?
Proposed PR merged
Proposed PR merged
Jaxb jars are all CDDL 1.1 licensed (category B list), so allowed but probably needs a tweak to NOTICE, LICENSE and/or README files. That's still on the TODO list.
merged - thanks

I think adding JDK10/11 is a good thing. I am not sure making them "consistent" when Java actually made a change helps us though. Once we also add a `isPostJDK10(bytecodeVersion)` method it will return true for JDK9 which returns '9' for `System.getProperty('java.specification.version')`.

We could still change the config option so that args to groovyc are similar to each other, but I guess keeping it consistent with java.specification.version makes sense.  `isPostJDK9()` is only used by tests it looked like at the moment, but it keeps the logic simpler there to make it match what Java returns.
No test added just yet but the bytecode looks good with visual inspection.
Looks good!
Merged. Thanks! I created this issue: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-8754
Merged. Thanks

Another issue is related to the PR:  
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-8212

@michelzanini as of Groovy 2.5.2/3.0.0-alpha-3 getters/setters and many methods added by core AST transformations are not marked with `@Generated`. This will change in future releases. https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-8765

Looks good. So just to confirm. It would never be needed for the core jar if it was using service loader? Just the fragment jars?

Also, it would be good to tweak to rule out when only org.codehaus.groovy.ast.builder.AstBuilderTransformation is found in the META-INF services directory. We should really move that to META-INF/groovy since defining a global transform isn't really a service. It only affects groovy-macro in your list. Let me know if you want to tweak your PR or otherwise I can make that change.

Yes, only the fragments should be needed to enhance. The provider bundles (fragments) bring the capability to to main bundle.

Do I understand right that org.codehaus.groovy.ast.builder.AstBuilderTransformation as a service should be escaped?
That's correct but let's just leave your PR as is. I'll make another issue to fix here we place global transformation meta-inf information.
I created GROOVY-8771 to track the other issue.
Okay, I'll keep the PR as is.
It seems this still need some work. I get exceptions while using woven groovy classes. :-(

Okay, I have a PR for GROOVY-8771 ready, though I doubt it will impact your testing. I'll hold off merging this PR until I head further. Perhaps add the new stacktrace with woven classes into the Jira issue.

Unfortunately it's the same exception. After a bit of debugging it seems that woving the class fail or could not be done but without any obvious reason (error). I think that need further investigation.

There was some push back on moving the global transforms META-INF files, so I'll leave them where they are for now. If you find a different solution for the other problems you were facing, I can help with the tweaks for the build to account for those files if you need me to.
Leaving files where they are for now. We can come back and re-look at this PR if additional impacts are found down the track.

After some investigation it now works. But I have to remove the classloader argument for my testing groovy bundle fragment (groovy-json) to get it be woven by spifly. This change is not added in this PR since this really might be problematic. I also have to add the spifly consumer capability together to the provider one.

@paulk-asert: How should we move forward?

I think we can probably proceed but can you elaborate a bit more on what you meant by "woven"? Is that Groovy traits or some other process you are using? I am still a little unsure of where your testing got you. Are the manifest changes you suggested good enough? Are others going to face the same issues you did?

Woven means that the spifly mediator adds his classloader switching functionality to bring consumer and provider together. This is done by adding code via asm to the groovy code itself. My test at the end is quite simple. I'm loading an osgi container (felix) together with spifly (+dependencies) + groovy + groovy-json and a simple bundle doing a really primitive groovy script:
`println new groovy.json.JsonSlurper().parseText('{\"2\":2}')`
Of cause it is very important to have the right order of bundles being deployed! Sometimes the order was wrong and I got other errors and didn't see the cause in the first moment. But this can be handled by example using karaf features or by hard coded order.
The manifest changes are simple the usage of what the OSGi standard says you should do.
Clear enough? :-)

I believe so. Just to make sure I understand, I'll try to restate. Let me know if this sounds right.

If we put your change in (give or take the changes wrt `AstBuilderTransformation` which I can look at), then it should fix the underlying problem. Folks who get the order right will have no problems. If someone gets the order wrong (from an OSGi point of view) then they might still get errors but it won't be due to a Groovy problem.

That's not 100% correct. As mentioned before I had to remove the classloader switch in groovy-json which is not part of this PR since I can not estimate if this will cause problems in normal (non-OSGi) usage. (https://github.com/apache/groovy/blob/GROOVY_2_5_X/subprojects/groovy-json/src/main/java/org/apache/groovy/json/internal/FastStringUtils.java#L40) I didn't look if this is done in any other groovy subproject, too. The rest of your statement is correct.

You removed the classloader parameter? Okay, that is different. What happens if you instead try adding a context classloader earlier? Thread.currentThread().setContextClassLoader(loader)? Not sure what loader will be for OSGi. It's been too long, I'd need to look that up again. Otherwise, is there any benefit to making the MANIFEST change?
Set tccl to tccl? I'm not sure what the classloader is really for in this context. In OSGi the tccl stuff is handled by weaving. Without removing the MANIFEST changes are useless!

I was suggesting something like what is shown here:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2198928/better-handling-of-thread-context-classloader-in-osgi
The actual code does use the tccl in groovy-json. No tccl switch as shown in your example. The question is if this really necessary?
